head.title: Actors on Strike: Support From the Many

hedline.hl1: Actors on Strike: Support From the Many

block.p: Re ''A Strike No One Can Win,'' by Leslie Saint Bornstein (Op-Ed, Sept. 29):

Regarding Ms. Bornstein's justification for her crossing of the Screen Actors Guild picket line, it isn't easy to get a union card, nor should it be. Acting is a competitive profession. Yet before the strike, in New York alone, the guild processed 100 new members a month. Each obtained a union job before becoming a member.
Re ''A Strike No One Can Win,'' by Leslie Saint Bornstein (Op-Ed, Sept. 29):

Regarding Ms. Bornstein's justification for her crossing of the Screen Actors Guild picket line, it isn't easy to get a union card, nor should it be. Acting is a competitive profession. Yet before the strike, in New York alone, the guild processed 100 new members a month. Each obtained a union job before becoming a member.
Ms. Bornstein says ''other unions aren't actively supporting this strike.'' In fact, Actors Equity and the Directors and Writers Guilds, among others, are supporting us.

This is a strike about earning a reasonable living wage. Union members understand this, as do the high-profile actors supporting the strike. Unions have always faced the reality that there are workers willing to undercut the many to advance their own selfish ends.
JOHN H. SUCKE Exec. Dir., New York Branch Screen Actors Guild New York, Oct. 3, 2000
